# Output Design

What is the range of the voltage-gain adjustment in the following circuit?

![](images/f02c80d56252e2203a7c7b6bcc1274c56dc86f3d530628537a5130be3bf174ac_50.jpg){width="50%"}

###### Solution:

$A_{\nu}=\frac{V_{o}}{V_{i}}=-\frac{R_{F}}{R_{l}}$

For $R_{1}=10$ k$\Omega$:

$A_{\nu}=-\frac{500\ k\Omega}{10\ k\Omega}$ = -50

For $R_{1}=20$ k$\Omega$:

$A_{\nu}=-\frac{500\ k\Omega}{20\ k\Omega}=-25$

- When a number of stages are connected in series, the overall gain is the product of the individual stage gains.

- Following figure shows a connection of three stages. The first stage is connected to provide noninverting gain. The next two stages provide an inverting gain.

- The overall circuit gain is then noninverting and is calculated by: $A = A_1A_2A_3$

where $A_{1} = 1 + R_{f}/R_{1}$, $A_{2} = -R_{f}/R_{2}$, and $A_{3} = -R_{f}/R_{3}$.

Consider a three-stage OP-AMP circuit with gains of +10, -18, and -27 and 270 kΩ feedback resistor for all three circuits. What output voltage V₀ will result for an input of 150 μV? Also find R₁, R₂, R₃ and total gain A.

Solution: For the gain of +10,

$$\begin{array}{rl} { A _ { 1 } } & { { } = 1 + { \frac { R _ { f } } { R _ { 1 } } } = + 10 } \\{ { \frac { R _ { f } } { R _ { 1 } } } } & { { } = 10 - 1 = 9 } \\{ R _ { 1 } } & { { } = { \frac { R _ { f } } { 9 } } = { \frac { 27 0 \, \mathrm { k } \Omega } { 9 } } = 30 \, \mathrm { k } \Omega } \end{array}$$

![](images/74049675fab21c86014f7da37fc71a50135f6894525f8054b58c8cd97cc2656a_51.jpg){width="51%"}

For the gain of $-18$,

$$\begin{array}{rl} { A _ { 2 } } & { { } = - { \frac { R _ { f } } { R _ { 2 } } } = - 18 } \\{ R _ { 2 } } & { { } = { \frac { R _ { f } } { 18 } } = { \frac { 27 0 \, \mathrm { k } \Omega } { 18 } } = 15 \, \mathrm { k } \Omega } \end{array}$$

For the gain of $-27$,

$$\begin{array}{rl} { A _ { 3 } } & { { } = - { \frac { R _ { f } } { R _ { 3 } } } = - 27 } \\{ R _ { 3 } } & { { } = { \frac { R _ { f } } { 27 } } = { \frac { 27 0 \, \mathrm { k } \Omega } { 27 } } = 10 \, \mathrm { k } \Omega } \end{array}$$

Total gain = $A = A_1A_2A_3 = (10)(-18)(-27) = 4860$

For an input of $V_{1}$ = 150 $\mu$V, the output voltage is

$V_{\mathrm{L}} = A_{1}A_{2}A_{3}V_{\mathrm{L}} = (10)(-18)(-27)(150\ \mu\mathrm{V}) = 4860(150$

$$\begin{array}{rl} & { V _ { o } = A _ { 1 } A _ { 2 } A _ { 3 } V _ { 1 } = ( 10 ) ( - 18 ) ( - 27 ) ( 15 0 \, \mu \mathrm { V } ) = 48 60 ( 15 0 \, \mu \mathrm { V } ) } \\& { = 0 . 72 9 \, \mathrm { V } } \end{array}$$

outputs that are 10, 20, and 50 times l feedback resistor of

Solution: The resistor component for each stage is calculated to be

Determine the output for the circuit in following figure with components $R_{f} = 1$ MΩ, $R_{1} = 100$ k Ω, $R_{2} = 50$ k Ω, and $R_{3} = 500$ k Ω.

Also find output of first OP-AMP.

###### Solution:

$$\begin{array}{rl} & { V _ { o 1 } = - \frac { R _ { f } } { R _ { 1 } } V _ { 1 } } \\& { V _ { o 1 } = - \frac { 1 \, M \Omega } { 10 0 \, K \Omega } V _ { 1 } = - 10 V _ { 1 } } \end{array}$$

![](images/1467ea922162332b39a2fc86fd74566429d10ef02257d49415116f74c3525aff_60.jpg){width="60%"}

The output voltage is then calculated to be: $V_{o} = -\left(\frac{1}{50\,\mathrm{k}\Omega}V_{2} - \frac{1}{500\,\mathrm{k}\Omega}\frac{1}{100\,\mathrm{k}\Omega}V_{1}\right) = -(20\,V_{2} - 20\,V_{1}) = -20(V_{2} - V_{1})$

The output is seen to be the difference of $V_{2}$ and $V_{1}$ multiplied by a gain factor of $-20$.

$$\begin{array}{rl} { \mathbf { F o r m u l a } \colon } & { } \\{ \mathbf { V _ { 0 } } = - \frac { \mathbf { R _ { f } } } { \mathbf { R _ { 1 } } } V _ { 1 } } & { } \\{ \mathbf { V _ { 0 } } = - \left( \frac { \mathbf { R _ { f } } } { \mathbf { R _ { 1 } } } V _ { 1 } + \frac { \mathbf { R _ { f } } } { \mathbf { R _ { 2 } } } V _ { 2 } + \frac { \mathbf { R _ { f } } } { \mathbf { R _ { 3 } } } V _ { 3 } \right) } & { } \end{array}$$
